item.title: Applications
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
Call for proposal

  • The objective of the 2016-19 call for projects is to support innovative projects in line with the thematic actions at the labex interfaces and to reinforce the opening of the labex internationally.

    There is no deadline for submissions; the call for proposals is open until the end of 2018.
    The Steering Committee meets quarterly to review the requests and the responses to the call for proposals.

  • Eligibility

    Only research projects in partnership with labex teams (see partners) are eligible for funding from labex. The credits are only paid to the members of the labex partner teams (except in the case of co-financing), external partners or foreign partners must be financed from other sources.

  • Eligible research themes

    Proposals for research projects must fit into one or more of the four thematic axes of the labex: CC1. Linear scaling of algorithms, CC2. Molecule energy approximation, CB1. Sequential algorithms improvement, CB2. Algorithms for genomics (see grand challenges).

    The proposals must show how they fit into these axes and how they foster interdisciplinary collaborations around modelling and numerical simulation.

  • Training and valorization

    A priority objective of the period 2016-19 is to promote the articulation between research and training. Training activities involving the research activities of the labex teams are strongly encouraged. As well as training activities of international scope and based on collaborative dissemination tools (E-learning, MOOC).


Funding

  • Nature of the support

    Within the framework of the call for projects 2016-19, labex will finance:

    - short stays of high-level scientists in one of the partner laboratories;
    - 4 doctoral grants (deadline 31/12/2016) including an allocation of 5000 euros (missions, small equipment) for co-directed theses;
    - 7 post-doctoral awards of 12 months including a grant of 3000 euros;
    - 1 fixed-term contract for an expert engineer (3 years max.) for one of the labex teams;
    - the organization of events (conferences, seminars, workshops, schools, specialized courses).

  • Eligibility conditions

    Eligible expenditure must comply with Article 3.4 of the Regulation Form of labex regarding the rules for granting aid, of June 7th, 2012. Capital expenditure of more than EUR 4000 are not eligible.

    Co-financing (ANR, European contracts, labex, ...) is strongly encouraged. The researchers are invited to study the possibility of co-financing the salaries of doctoral students and post-doctoral students recruited on labex credits.


Submit a proposal

  1. call for proposal

    please consult first the text of the call for proposal

  2. documents to be completed

    To facilitate the processing of responses, the following forms are available.
    Please fill them in and submit them with the attachments (.zip, .tar, .gz archive formats) by email to iscd@upmc.fr.

    thesis/postdoctoral project (or download PDF format )

    grant application (invitation, organization of events, training courses) (or download PDF format )

    recruitment of a research engineer (contact us)

  3. expertise of applications

    Applications are evaluated by the members of the labex steering committee and by external members if necessary. The results of the evaluation are emailed to the applicants after the Steering Committee meetings.

item.title: Grand challenges
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
State of the art

  • Computational chemistry is a natural outgrowth of theoretical chemistry and comes from the early attempts of theoretical physicists to solve the Schr√∂dinger wave equation on computers.

    The bottleneck for ab-initio studies of molecules is related to the extremely small number of configurations that can be explored and thus many properties are not directly accessible using these approaches. Many problems in numerical analysis are at hand, including the generation and manipulation of large numbers of six-dimensional integrals, finding eigenvalues and eigenvectors of large matrices, or searching a complicated function for global and local minima and saddle points.

    The growing interest in theoretical-computational chemistry has led to the development of software applications that are widely available and account for much of the CPU usage at the supercomputing centres worldwide.

    One major and worthwhile improvement to reduce this computational cost could be to better exploit the symmetry of the molecules. However, it faces the challenge of determining the proper size of the space of configurations, as well as the optimal number of parameters required to yield reliable values of the properties.

  • Computational biology & bioinformatics involve the development and application of theoretical models and methods, data analysis and computer simulation techniques in the study of biological systems. In these disciplines, computational challenges are arising following the exponential growth of sequences and databases, and the discovery of complex biomolecular interactions.

    Today the limited computer power available together with the sequential nature of the algorithms is the main obstacles for advancing research in computational biology. To achieve more effectiveness in statistical genetics and genomics from new computer technologies it is of paramount importance to better parallelise the codes. This can only be achieved by bringing together computing experts and biostatisticians.


Four grand challenges

CalsimLab objectives are to build a coherent theoretical background, develop adapted numerical methods and implement efficient algorithms, for the following four Grand Challenges:

  1. linear scaling in computational chemistry

    covers the need to design and implement a reliable and efficient procedure taking into account electronic correlation that would scale almost linearly with the system size. This is currently a scientific computing hurdle that prevents the use of computational chemistry in many applications in which biomolecular interactions are at play.

  2. molecule energy approximation in computational chemistry

    is related to overcoming the simpler approximations of the Schr√∂dinger equations that have been introduced by chemists to estimate the energy of molecules from ground states to excited states. This representation of energy has made the modelling of biological systems possible but the approach suffers from two drawbacks: i) only structural types previously encountered in smaller molecules can be parameterised for larger molecules and ii) the connection to the SchroÃàdinger equation is unclear.

  3. sequential algorithms in computational biology

    many problems in computational biology rely on sequential algorithms that are significantly difficult for software engineers to parallelise and adapt. This is a major hurdle that prevents full benefit from the forthcoming HPC infrastructures. Some methods in use are known to be NP-hard (i.e., do not scale linearly). One potential roadmap to ensure that these analysis algorithms remain computationally feasible for large datasets is to take advantage of cutting-edge linear algebra libraries set for multi-core and GPU technologies.

  4. algorithms for genomics

    algorithms are used to explore data and discover laws of evolution that affect genomes and molecules and that requires validation against experimental data. Integrative genomics analysis, requires efficient tools to tackle the joint analysis of various types of genomics information. The challenge is that multivariate models have to be implemented in ultra-high dimensional data and coupled with inferential algorithms that search over vast model spaces. As the size of the genomics data sets and the number of samples are constantly increasing, the mathematical computations as well as the computational complexity become exponentially more expensive.

item.content:encoded:
Popular resources

Welcome to ISCD's intranet section. We invite your questions and feedback as we are working to improve this site.
Please send us an email to get help or make a suggestion.

But, what exactly is this intranet ? Well, according to Wikipedia, intranet is:
‚Äú...a private network, accessible only to an organization's staff....[and] can constitute an important focal point of internal communication and collaboration, and provide a single starting point to access internal and external resources.‚Äù

Actually, ISCD simply needed a section of pages, some of them password protected, to keep information limited to specific audiences, as well as a portal for link and resources. Hence, you will find here a collection of links, documents and stuffs that cannot fit easily in the other pages of our site.

Utilisation des moyens de l'institut

toto

Visioconf√©rence

  • Pour quoi faire?

    • En salle 201 se trouve un dispositif de visioconf√©rence, permettant de rejoindre des salles virtuelles de visioconf√©rence par adresse IP. Le dispositif consiste en une cam√©ra et un micro, situ√©s au dessus de la t√©l√©vision, un bo√Ætier branch√© √† la t√©l√©vision et permettant notamment de brancher un ordinateur pour du partage d'√©cran, et la t√©l√©vision en elle m√™me.
    Le service le plus utilis√© dans notre cas d'utilisation est RENAVisio, mais d'autres passerelles peuvent √™tre utilis√©es.

  • Qu'est-ce-que RENAVisio?

    • Extraits des sites respectifs:
    RENAvisio est un service de pont de visioconf√©rence √† r√©servation instantan√©e, pour la communaut√© RENATER. Outre la r√©servation de visioconf√©rences planifi√©es, RENAvisio permet √† tout utilisateur de r√©server instantan√©ment (en un clic) les ressources pour une r√©union. En plus de la visioconf√©rence IP, RENAvisio permet un acc√®s voix et image par t√©l√©phone ou RNIS.
    RENATER, R√©seau National de t√©l√©communications pour la Technologie l‚ÄôEnseignement et la Recherche, a √©t√© d√©ploy√© au d√©but des ann√©es 90 pour f√©d√©rer les infrastructures de t√©l√©communication pour la recherche et l‚Äô√©ducation. Afin de mener √† bien cette action, le Groupement d‚ÄôInt√©r√™t Public RENATER a √©t√© constitu√© en f√©vrier 1993.

  • Comment cr√©er ou planifier une visioconf√©rence?

    • Sur le site de RENAvisio, se connecter avec un identifiant officiel (UPMC ou autre √©tablissement membre de RENATER).
    RENAvisio propose alors deux choix: la cr√©ation d'une conf√©rence instantan√©e, ou la planification d'une conf√©rence.
    Remplir les champs demand√©s, en s'assurant dans "Options avanc√©es" que la case "scopia" est bien coch√©e.
    En cliquant sur "Cr√©er", des informations devraient appara√Ætre √† l'√©cran et un mail vous √™tre envoy√© sur l'adresse de connexion.
    Voir la question sur la connexion

  • Comment inviter des participants √† rejoindre une vid√©oconf√©rence?

    • Une fois la conf√©rence cr√©√©e, il "suffit" de transf√©rer les informations de la page de r√©sum√© ou du mail √† votre interlocuteur: en particulier, l'adresse IP (123.456.78.901), l'identifiant de la r√©union (en 6 chiffres), et le mot de passe (en 4 chiffres).
    √Ä partir de ces informations, votre interlocuteur devrait pouvoir rejoindre la visioconf√©rence avec son propre dispositif, ou avec un des logiciels √©num√©r√©s ci-dessous

  • Comment se connecter √† une visioconf√©rence √† partir du dispositif de visioconf√©rence?

    • Allumer la t√©l√©vision (t√©l√©commande "SONY" noire).
    S'assurer que la source s√©lectionn√©e correspond √† la sortie du bo√Ætier Polycom
    Allumer le bo√Ætier Polycom (avec la t√©l√©commande grise, ou en appuyant sur le bouton tactile situ√© sur le bo√Ætier)
    Le dispositif devrait s'allumer. Quelques minutes peuvent √™tre n√©cessaires pour red√©marrer compl√®tement le syst√®me.
    A partir du menu principal, naviguer avec les fl√®ches de la t√©l√©commande Polycom jusqu'√† l'item "Appeler", et valider.
    Dans le champ libre, rentrer l'adresse IP fournie par RENAvisio ou par votre interlocuteur, et valider.
    Le syst√®me devrait vous demander l'identifiant de la conf√©rence. Pour le rentrer, appuyer une premi√®re fois sur di√®se, rentrer l'identifiant, et valider avec di√®se de nouveau.
    Renseigner le mot de passe de la r√©union.
    Si tout s'est bien pass√©, vous devriez maintenant √™tre connect√© √† la visioconf√©rence. Sinon, consulter la question "Que faire en cas de probl√®mes?"

  • Quel logiciel(s) utiliser sur un ordinateur pour rejoindre une visioconf√©rence?

item.title: FAQ
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
Frequently Asked Questions

  1. What is CalsimLab ?

    2. In 2012, the French "Excellence Initiative" (PIA2) granted UPMC with a Laboratory of Excellence grant (labex), CalsimLab.
    CalsimLab focuses on currently very active research areas ‚Äî computational chemistry and computational biology & bioinformatics ‚Äîand gathers scientists from chemistry, physics, and microbiology together with applied mathematicians and scientists in computer science, mechanics and engineering.
    The labex received 5 million euros in funding for a 8-year period, essentially devoted to advancement of science projects through the recruitment of PhD students, post-doctoral fellows and research engineers.

  2. Does Calsimlab provide scholarships for students?

    3. Yes. CalsimLab provides scholarships and 3-year doctoral grants for highly talented students willing to pursue their studies at PhD level after their master degree. The conditions to get a grant are: excellent academic records; do the internship/thesis in one of the Labex research teams (see lists of associated labs/partners); and work in one of the main labex research domains. The PhD positions are open to students from all countries. The candidate should be proficient in English (or French). Foreign candidates will be expected to follow basic French training during the first year of their appointment.
    The successful candidates will receive a monthly gross salary of 2,025 ‚Ç¨ (medical coverage and benefits included).
    The application procedure is described here.

  3. How can I determine if CalsimLab is interested in providing funds for my conference or meeting?

    4. First check and get in touch with the labex representatives in your discipline or science area (i.e. the steering committee members) for your proposed conference or meeting. Upon approval, fill up the application form and email it to iscd@upmc.fr.

  4. How will my proposal be evaluated?

    5. The steering committee will evaluate the proposals every three months. Each applicant will receive a short notification of the decision by email shortly after the meeting.

  5. How should i mention the labex in my publications?

    6. CalsimLab Partners should mention their lab/unit in their author‚Äôs affiliations according to UPMC-SU policy.
    It is mandatory, however, to mention the ANR reference number of the Labex fund in the Funding or Acknowledgment sections if i) the study is totally or partially funded by CalsimLab grants or ii) participants in the study are supported by a labex fellowship/scholarship.
    Funding: "This study was supported by grants from the Labex CalsimLab, reference ANR-11-LABX-0037-01. The labex CalsimLab is funded by the program ‚ÄúInvestissements d‚Äôavenir‚Äù of the Agence Nationale de la Recherche, reference ANR-11-IDEX-0004-02".
    Acknowledgments:
    "[Name] was supported by a labex CalsimLab fellowship/scholarship. The labex Calsimlab, reference ANR-11-LABX-0037-01, is funded by the program ‚ÄúInvestissements d‚Äôavenir‚Äù of the Agence Nationale de la Recherche, reference ANR-11-IDEX-0004-02."

item.title: Catalogue
item.dc:creator: miskiewicz
item.content:encoded:
Services

ISCD provides help desk, consulting services and support for High Performance Computing at UPMC. Our systems are a shared Linux environment with most of the popular applications, compilers and programs installed. We work with faculty and research groups across disciplines to design and maintain cost-effective computing facilities.

For additional help see our wiki section or contact us at mesu@upmc.fr.

User support services are based on supporting individuals. Technical support is subdivided into levels, in order to better serve our HPC users. The reason for providing a multi-tiered support system instead of one general support group is to provide the best possible service in the most efficient possible manner.

Support is available on Monday through Friday, 9am - 5pm, except holidays.

Multi-tiered support

The following table describes the multi-tiered technical support provided by MeSU technicians and ISCD experts.

Abbrv. Services Features Covers Pricing
WP-L0 Welcome Package
Level 0		 - provide access to computational ressources: creation and activation of an account (see wiki for technical specifications); allocation of quotas (hours, disk, CPU); access to standard software libraries through 'modules'; - registration to next training session (consult calendar) system administrator
MeSU HPC - ViSU centre
self-help (wiki, forum)		 free of charge
BUI-L1 Basic User Issues
Level 1		 - gather user information and determine issue (analyze symptoms, figure out problems) - troubleshooting methods, resolve username and password problems, uninstalling/reinstalling software applications/librairies, check hardware and software setup, - provide assistance in using basic applications. system administrator additional competency (if needed) to be defined
IdTS-L2 In-depth Technical Support
Level 2		 - advanced technical troubleshooting and analysis methods: confirm BUI-L1 diagnosis; - collect information on program that failed, or data related details; - diagnostic testing, use of remote tools to fix the problem (compiler, makefile, exec file, etc.) system administrator user HPC engineer to be defined
BeTS-L3 Back-end Technical Support
Level 3		 - research and development to known and new issues; - review the work order; - assess the solution; - access to user code or data to analyze it system administrator HPC engineer developer or code expert to be defined

Tailored software development

Implementing software solutions to one problem is becoming more and more complex. ISCD offers development of efficient software intended to meet HPC users‚Äô demands. Our specialists, assisted by leading experts from UPMC and SU laboratories, will thoroughly analyze your problem and help you create successful solutions that match with all the requirements, in budget and on schedule. We master all levels of software complexity.

Abbrv. Services Features Covers Pricing
Tail-L4 Tailored Development
Level 4		 - identification of needs - planning: scope document - designing: software design document a proof of concept may be produced at this stage system administrator research engineer expert scientists to be defined
Tail-L5 Tailored Development
Level 5		 - implementation, testing, documenting: code programming, checking defects, test-driven developments, implementation's correctness - deployment, maintenance: release (license), installation, customization and evaluation - performance engineering system administrator research engineer expert scientists PhDs, post-docs to be defined

HPC On-demand Pricing

to be completed.


Multi-tiered technical support

Technical support is subdivided into tiers, or levels, in order to better serve HPC users. The reason for providing a multi-tiered support system instead of one general support group is to provide the best possible service in the most efficient possible manner. ISCD support structure involves a three-tiered technical support system.

  • Level 0 (or self-help)
    is mostly in the form of "wikis" or FAQs (forum) that allow for users to access and resolve information on their own rather have to contact the local help desk for resolution.

  • Level 1
    is the initial support level responsible for basic user issues. This level is intended at gathering as much information as possible from the users. This information is useful to analyze the symptoms to define the problem or issue, and is recorded into the issue logging system. Technical support specialists typically handle straightforward and simple problems.

  • Level 2
    is a more in-depth technical support level than the previous levels. The technicians are more experienced and knowledgeable on the HPC system. They are responsible for assisting Level 1 personnel in solving basic technical problems and for investigating elevated issues by confirming the validity of the problem and seeking for known solutions related to these issues. This team collects information such as program name that is failed or application name or any data related details.

  • Level 3
    is the highest level of support in our three-tiered technical support model responsible for handling the most difficult or advanced problems. It involves expert level troubleshooting and analysis methods. The experts are responsible with the research and development of solutions to new or unknown issues. It is typical for a developer or someone who knows the code, to be a Level 3 support person. Some extreme problems can be send to the original developers to be investigated. If it is determined that the problem can be solved, this group is responsible for designing and developing one or more courses of action, evaluating each of these courses in a test case environment, and implementing the best solution to the problem.

item.title: Support
item.dc:creator: miskiewicz
item.content:encoded:
HPC user support

High Performance Computing (HPC) Support Team runs, maintains and administers MeSU HPC facilities. Use of MeSU's HPC facility is offered free of charge for all members of UPMC and Sorbonne Universit√©s or, for academic and industrial partners, provided at cost (consult our new accounts page for more details).

Advice and support

Free support is provided by the HPC Support Team.

Researchers running HPC or data analysis projects on MeSU should get in touch to discuss the best system for requirements. The HPC team will work with you, upon request, to determine the computational requirements of your programs and create an appropriate system specification to match. We organize basic training sessions to ensure that users have the minimum skills required to use the system.

Full end-to-end support is available on a contract basis for companies. It provides flexible and reliable enterprise level technology and scientific support.

Send us an email to discover more about this program.

The HPC Team can arrange training courses for HPC users, in cooperation with the training centre of Maison de la Simulation (Paris-Saclay). Courses may be scheduled upon request and are delivered by experts. Courses are tailored to the needs of HPC users.

item.title: Contact
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
MeSU technical support

If you experience any problem with HPC resources, or if you have a query not covered by the online documentation or the wiki pages, please email the support team mesu@upmc.fr

  • Compilation failures: please email the support team and provide the following information:

    • a short explanation of what you are trying to achieve
    • the output of the 'makefile' or compilation command and the command you ran which leads to the failure
    • the full path to your working (compilation) directory

  • Job failures: in case a job fails to run and you are unable to find why, please supply us with the following information:

    • the ID of the job
    • a brief description of the job
    • the full path to the directory from which the job was submitted
    • the name and location of the submission script and the exact command used to submit.

  • Application/libraries requests: if you would like a specific library or (open-source) application to be installed, please email the support team with the following information:

    • the name of the library/application
    • the website of the library/application (if you know it)
    • the reason you would like to have it installed
    • any specific requirements (e.g. 32/64 bits).

Feedback

MeSU team welcomes feedback on topics such as opportunities for future services, and how current offerings can be improved. Please email mesu@upmc.fr.

item.title: Accounts
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
User accounts

HPC accounts are available for all UPMC and SU faculty, research staff, and graduate students with the approval of a qualified PI, for the purpose of research.

For any questions about qualifying for a HPC account, please contact MeSU Service Desk.

Users can subscribe at any time of the year. Accounts are granted to users for one full year max. or upon the completion of the specified project (plan B only). Researchers must share the facility, and jobs are limited to ensure that each one gets a fair share of the resources.

see the new webpage to find how to apply for an account.

item.title: Applications
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
Secure your place!

Courses have a maximum tutorial size of 40 students. Participants must be aged between 18-25 at the time of attendance and must be duly registered in a licence (L3) or master course (M1-M2). At the end of the summer school, each student will get an assistance certificate signed by school coordinators.

The school is generously supported by ISCD's training program through the Calsimlab labex initiative, which provide scholarship grants. These scholarships cover the participation and accommodation fees for all selected students.

Application information

The application period for admission to the summer school program is open from March 15th until June 15, 2017.
Candidates who apply during this time will be considered for admission. The Summer School Steering Committee will select the 40 max. students who will attend the school, based on their academic merit. Selected participants will be notified by the June 20, 2017.

Selection of participants will be based to a large extend on their scientific interests and academic background. Please take your time and think carefully before explaining who you are and what are your motivations for attending the summer school.

The language of the school and the entire program will be English; participants must be able to communicate freely in English.

Application process

Applications must be made via the application form, which requires that prospective candidates write a concise statement of their academic background. Participation is only possible for students who stay during the entire duration of the school (exception may be made for schools composed of two thematic parts).

Before you apply, you should have the following information and documents ready:

  • Personal data: lastname, first name, date of birth, gender, postal and email addresses;
  • High school: name, city, and country, year of graduation;
  • University: name, city, and country, year of enrollment;
  • Copy of your University ID card and copy of your last diploma;
  • Citizenship, visa information: do you need a visa for France?
  • Copy of your passport or ID card;
  • Information about one scholar who can provide a recommendation letter for you; be sure to inform your referee, and have their valid email addresses;

Once you are ready to apply, follow the following steps:

  1. download the Summer School Application form (Word or PDF format) and fill it out;

  2. create a single PDF or an archive file (.zip, .gz, .tar) with all the requested documents;

  3. email the PDF or the archive file to training_iscd@upmc.fr;

item.title: Information
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
Enroll now

Our programme is a residential summer course consisting of academic classes, hands-on sessions and extracurricular activities in the picturesque city of Roscoff, on the coast of Brittany. The programme 2017 runs in the following 2 week sessions:

  • Session 1: 17th July ‚Äì 28th July 2017; Bioinformatics;
  • Session 2: 31st July ‚Äì 11th August 2017; Visual data analysis;

Consult our brochure describing this year programme and submit your application if interested.

We would be happy to assist you if you have any questions prior to booking your place.
For the fastest response to your enquiry, please email: training_iscd@upmc.fr

Timetable

The Summer School schedule offers a wide range of unique academic and extracurricular opportunities.

Participants start off the day with a continental breakfast in the Gulf Stream dining room. This is followed by the first lecture session of the day, which takes place in the main amphitheater. Participants are then guided to lunch back at the Gulf Stream hotel. Following lunch, sessions continue in the format of hands-on numerical activities or workshops. Dinner will take place in the dining room and after, participants are invited to wind down and socialise before resuming the activities the next day.

Accomodation

The event is hosted at the beautiful Marine Station in Roscoff, located on the northern coast of Brittany.

  • Location

    The Roscoff Station is a CNRS Conference Centre and offers all infrastructure for organising university-level courses and hands-on sessions. All courses will take place in the conference room (auditorium) located on the second floor of Yves Delage building. Hands-on sessions will be carried out in the computer room located in the Hotel de France building.

  • Accomodation in residence

    The Gulf Stream residence has 41 single rooms and 6 double rooms available to student participants. The restaurant is open for lunch and dinners for guests as well as for the Marine Station staff. It is famous among the community for the quality of its food and its service. An access code will be given to you upon your arrival to allow you to enter the Gulf Stream hotel.

    To facilitate your travel plans, you are welcome to arrive at the station the day before the school starts and leave the day after its ending.

  • Computers and electronics

    The Gulf Stream and all facilities at Roscoff Marine Station are equipped with a wireless network. You will be registered as UPMC students during the summer school and will be provided with a login and password to connect. If you have problem connecting to the network, please contact the teaching assistants that will notify the Roscoff Station‚Äôs IT officer.

  • Coming to Roscoff

    The grant for the Summer School is not inclusive of travel to Roscoff.

    There are several transport options available, including arriving in Roscoff by rail, coach or flight.

    If you have chosen to travel by train you will arrive at the Roscoff train station. Departure is scheduled at Paris Montparnasse train station. Train platform will be announced 20 minutes before departure. Take the TGV train to Morlaix and then change for a regional express train (or a bus, if indicated).

User Committee

The user committee was established in 2017. Its purpose is to provide advice and feedback to the MeSU center for high-performance computing management and technicians about the current state and future delivery of resources and services. The objective is to enhance the effective use of the MeSU facilities by sharing information, suggesting improvements in scientific computing and raising user concerns.

item.title: Resources
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
Data Visualisation centre

The Centre for Data Visualisation (CDV) allows researchers from different disciplines to explore and analyse complex and heterogeneous data. A wide interactive stereoscopic projection screen allows the scientists to explore their data sets, in view of improving the understanding of scientific questions and challenges.

Display system

CDV uses a front projection-based stereoscopic visualisation environment with an approximately 6 x 2.5 m wide screen. Two projectors are used to achieve a resolution of approximately 3,800 by 1,400 pixels. Stereoscopic view is achieved using technology-active glasses, images are generated alternating for the left and the right eye. Infrared cameras can detect passive markers on the user‚Äôs 3D glasses.

The rendering is performed using a HP workstation equipped with two Nvidia Quadro K5200 graphics processing units (GPUs). The local workstation is remotely connected to MeSU HPC systems (located on campus), which allow the users to visualise their data without transfer overhead.

Reservation

The visualisation room (hall 33-34, room 203) is reservable for up to 2 months in advance, and for up to 24 hours, by faculty, staff or graduate students:

  • check the planning to see when Room 203 is available;

  • send a message to contact_iscd@upmc.fr, with your full name, laboratory/structure, purpose of the meeting, the meeting date + time (from-to), and the numbers of attendees.
    Incomplete information demand will be discarded.


Stereoscopic visualisation environment

Check if room available

The visualisation room 203 must be booked in advance via ISCD staff. Check the planning below before sending email.

item.title: Facile
item.dc:creator: loicNorgeot
item.content:encoded:
FaciLe <1/6>

Facial reconstruction

from sculpture to mathematical modelling

With the chair FaciLe, ISCD opened an innovative research field: the use of scientific computing, mathematical modelling and 3D visualization to virtually reconstruct the face of a person from his digitized cranium. At stake: applications in forensics, but also in paleontology and archeology. The objective is to explore innovative approaches to pave the way for effective and robust digital 3D facial reconstruction tools. Reconstituting an individual's face from the skeleton of his skull is often the last resort when all other methods of identifying human remains have failed. But this method can also be used in paleontology and archeology - for example, to put a face on the ancestors of Homo sapiens or on a historical figure. The traditional technique for three-dimensional forensic facial reconstruction is to sculpt the face by hand. Problem: it leaves a large place to the subjectivity of the artist. Frequently, faces reconstituted in this way do not allow to identify an individual. Hence the idea of using mathematical modelling techniques to obtain a more objective and reliable result, and also to quickly propose several versions of a reconstructed face in order to facilitate identification. FaciLe <2/6>

Forensic facial reconstruction

a subjective yet effective technique

Despite being disputed, notably for its subjectivity, this technique has proved successful and several research teams are actively advancing this topic worldwide. The first facial reconstitution is credited to the German anatomist W. His in 1895 who reconstructed the face of composer J.S. Bach. Nowadays, with the advent of 3D technology, effective computerized facial reconstruction programs have been developed. Primarily two types of reconstruction techniques are available. They all require the collaboration of artists, forensic anthropologists, maxillo-facial surgeons and other experts.
  • Two-dimensional reconstructionsThey are based on antemortem photographs and the visual analysis of the skull which provides clues to the physical appearance. This method was first developed during the 1980's. Available computer programs (like CARES: Computer Assisted Recovery Enhancement System and FACES: Forensic Anthropology Computer Enhancement System) allow to quickly generate two-dimensional approximations of a generic visage that can be easily modified by the expert or the artist. Fig. 1: two-dimensional manual method (from C. Wilkinson, J. Anat., 2010).
  • Three-dimensional reconstructionsThe manual method uses clay, plastic or wax directly on a replica of the skull. It relies on the use of markers to represent soft tissue depths that are inserted into small holes on the skull cast at specific landmarks (anthropometerical method) or on using facial muscles in anatomical position (Gerasimov's anatomical method) or taking both into consideration (British method). Fig. 2: three-dimensional manual method (from C. Wilkinson, J. Anat., 2010).Efficient digital facial reconstruction methods have been developed using animation software (free form modelling) to model the face onto the skull, or to digitally sculpt the visage using haptic devices, or event to warp a visage onto the skull via mathematical models. These techniques require both anthropological and computer modelling skills, reduce notably the subjectivity and allow to quickly create several avatars of the same visage. Fig. 3: three-dimensional computerized method (from C. Wilkinson, J. Anat., 2010).
FaciLe <3/6>

Anatomical modelling

similarities and differences

The facial reconstruction procedure involves morphological and anatomical analysis. At this early stage of the facial reconstruction process, anthropologists and facial surgeons will provide accurate information about the muscles as well as other anatomical structures.
  • MusclesWe know from anatomy that all faces have in common the same set of muscles with the same origins and attachments. However, these muscles may differ largely in shape, size and position from one individual to another, in relation to the underlying bone structure.A thorough inspection of the mandible will allow to locate the inferior border of the large masseter muscle. Indeed, its size and activity has a direct influence on the craniofacial morphology of the individual.
  • Morphological considerationsThe determination of the facial features is carried out by carefully scrutinizing the skull according to a protocol governed by a few anatomical principles, giving very little room for subjectivity (i.e. artistic interpretation).At first, we investigate the eye morphology and the position of the eyeball in the orbit, bearing in mind the description given by Whitnall (a 24-mm diameter eyeball, a 12-mm diameter iris and the eyelids hugging the eyeball closely whilst clipping the edge of the iris as they cross the eyeball).Unsurprisingly, the nose is a feature deemed difficult to reconstruct accurately although there have been numerous studies assessing the relationship between the configuration of the nasal tissue with the bones surrounding the nasal aperture: nose will be wider than the bony aperture, the bony nasal aperture will be at most three-fifths of the overall width of the soft nose (Gerasimov) and the nasal base angle is determined by the direction of the nasal spine. Likewise, ear shape is also very difficult to determine precisely. Gerasimov considered the angle of the ear to be parallel to the jaw line and postulated that the earlobe attachment was related to the mastoid processes. The mouth is probably the part of the face which is more prone to artistic interpretation. We know however that its shape is related to the occlusion of the teeth, the dental pattern and the facial profile,but the shape of the vermillion line is difficult to predict accurately.
  • Dressing with a skin layerAt last, the reconstruction process will add a skin layer to cover the underlying bone and muscle structure taking into account the average thickness of soft tissue. Obviously, taking care of morphological details is important for the rendering and the interpretation, in relation with the age of the individual. Actually, the elastic properties of the skin evolve with the age of the person, wrinkles may appear as well as sagging of flesh and a decrease of adiposity. External as well as genetic factors may influence this ageing process and it is thus difficult to predict the texture of the face with accuracy, and this may jeopardize the reconstruction process.
FaciLe <4/6>

Assessing the results

quantification of facial shape

First and foremost, computer-aided facial reconstruction remains an approximation technique; it is based on the assumption that there exists a direct relationship between the skull and the soft tissue envelope. Hence, important issues need to be addressed regarding the accuracy, reliability and reproducibility of the models and results. Otherwise, its success and efficiency may be disputed.
  • A reference validation databasea reference validation dataset should be set up and opened to the research and forensic community for rigorous and independent assessment. Secondly, the power of these automated methods lies in the use of statistical information extracted from sufficiently large (male/female, span- ning different age intervals and ethnic groups) data- bases of the complex interrelationship of the skull and facial surface. Such information can be extracted from conventional CT scans or, even better, as advocated in the section on data acquisition, CBCT scans, since these are taken in an upright position with less radia- tion dose for almost similar image quality compared to conventional CT. Again, once sufficient objective evi- dence is gathered from pilot studies that CFR proce- dures using (CB)CT-based information result in acceptable reconstructions, efforts need to be under- taken to standardise and disseminate protocols for acquisition of such data for different populations. Finally, for the ‚Äòautomated‚Äô claim of these computer- ised methods to hold, further improvements are required in the image-processing chain to make such algorithms robust in the presence of the incomplete data available.
The process of constructing faces from skulls is known as facial approximation, among other names (e.g., facial reconstruction, facial reproduction). Since the aim of forensic facial approximation is to build a face from a skull that can be specifically and purposefully recognized as the person to whom the skull belongs (Neave and Prag 1997, Taylor 2001), accurate facial approximations are those that can be easily recognized correctly as the target individual (individual to whom the skull belongs) (Stephan 2002a). True success in facial approxi- mation depends, therefore, on purposeful facial recognition and is distinct from forensic case success where correct matching may result from factors other than purposeful recognition of the facial approximation. Such factors include: contextual information, e.g., belongings of individuals found at the crime scene along with the skeleton (Haglund and Reay 1991), and chance (Henneberg and Stephan 2001), but also other factors like the eagerness of people who know a missing person to gain emotional closure through the iden- tification of a loved one. A final, but critical element in the design of a compu- terised CFR technique is the evaluation of the accu- racy of the reconstructions obtained. Unfortunately, a rigorous validation is lacking in most of the studie involving computerised craniofacial reconstruction or is based on just a few examples of reconstructions qualified as successful based on subjective assessment of resemblance. Much of the information is anecdo- tal. More extensive resemblance-based validation studies, involving also unsuccessful cases, as well as quantitative studies are required if these CFR techniques are to become accepted in forensic science investigations and satisfy test of evidence in the courts (Wilkinson, 2005). Computer-based validations are possible given a database of skulls with known facial appearance. A typical validation scenario can, for instance, be based on leave-one-out cross-validation. Here every skull in the database is removed in turn and used as a test case. The resulting facial skin surface of the reconstruction technique can then be compared with the form of the actual skin surface of the test case. The form of the actual skin surface is the golden standard or ground truth of the validation setup, enabling evaluations of the reconstruction result. As a first instance, a quantitative reconstruction error evaluation can be performed, by observing local dimensional surface differences. Comparing the two surfaces in this quantitative way is interesting for evaluating the reconstruction performance in terms of accuracy and provides a spatial map of the difficulty of each facial region to be reconstructed (Berar et al., 2006; Vandermeulen et al., 2006; Claes et al., 2010a). Figure 17.18 shows the differences as obtained by the method of Claes and colleagues (Claes et al., 2010a), averaged over 12 test subjects for four different CFR methods, plotted on an average facial template. These results indicate that the use of face-specific mapping models (M0 and M1) outperform the generic models (M2 and M3). However, the final goal of CFR is not reconstruc- tion accuracy, but rather recognition or identification success. A recognition test consists of comparing the CFR result with a database of candidates including the ground truth or the actual person. The goal is to retrieve the ground truth from the database. In a computer-based recognition setup this can be accom- plished automatically using facial measures of similar- ity (Vandermeulen et al., 2006; Claes et al., 2010a), which is currently an active research topic (Smeets et al., 2010). A more realistic, human subjective, identification process can be simulated by generating face-pool tests (Moyers, 2007). Given an image of the CFR and a set of possible candidate images extracted from the database, a human observer is asked to indicate the face from the face-pool most similar to the given CFR. An interest- ing future alternative, based on the work found in Hill et al. (2010), could be the straightforward translation of physical differences or computer-based measures of similarity into perceived human-based differences, omitting the need for cumbersome face-pool testing. FaciLe <5/6>

Perception, recognition

when identification is at stake

The task of the anthropologist working with human remains or of a police officer investigating a criminal case is to establish formally an identity of a person (victim). This may involve dealing with a three-dimensional reconstruction of the face from the skull. Once it has been obtained, it still need to be identified. Accurate reconstructions are those that can be easily recognized correctly as the target individual. Here, success is different from forensic success where correct matching may result from contextual elements or luck. It is generally acknowledged that face recognition is predominantly performed in the right hemisphere of the brain, in which there is a specific region (the fusiform face area) that responds strongly to face stimuli. The left hemisphere may be specialized for featural processing. Appropriate contextual information is also very important in recognition although sometimes context can play some strange tricks.
  • Familiar facesto deal with supposedly 'familiar' faces, V. Bruce (2012) proposed a flow model to describe three consecutive broad stages in person recognition:
    • step 1 is to match the incoming visual pattern against a stored visual representation of what that person looks like. If there is a match at this level then the pattern may be recognized as 'familiar';
    • step 2 involves retrieving information about why the person is familiar (where you know them from, what they do for a living, etc.);
    • step 3 involves retrieving their name.
    In this model, the steps shall occur in this strict order. For instance, there is a good deal of evidence that name retrieval cannot occur before something else about the person is known. Unfortunately, problems can arise at any of these stages. A person may be not recognized at all, or may be misidentified because the visual pattern gets matched to the wrong stored visual representation. At the second stage, a person may seem familiar, but the details may be elusive or misremembered.
  • Unfamiliar facesin contrast to our ability with familiar faces, we are in general really rather poor at processing unfamiliar ones. Attempting to match a person to their photograph is highly error-prone. We tend to rely on superficial properties or features (hair, surface marks, etc.) and changes of lighting, viewpoint or expression greatly affect recognition performance. However, modest training experience of a face seems enough to improve the performance as it start the transition towards a more familiar style of face processing.
FaciLe <6/6>

Archeological investigations

reviving the past

Archaeological investigations provide challenging facial analysis opportunities to depict faces from the past, to show the public how these ancient people looked and to enable comparison with contemporary faces (Prag & Neave, 1997). They may also provide different types of material compared to forensic investigations and the amount of artistic inter- pretation may be greater, depending on the level of preser- vation. In forensic cases it is preferable to include only appearance details that have been ascertained directly from scene evidence, and not to estimate any unknowns, as incorrectly estimated details may confuse and discourage recognition and identification (Wilkinson, 2004). However, in archaeological investigations recognition of the face is rarely the primary objective and producing the most likely depiction may be more important than individual identity. In these cases the archaeologist will suggest the most prob- able hairstyle, hair colour, skin colour and eye colour from historical textual and pictorial evidence.

item.title: Numero
item.dc:creator: Bartette
item.content:encoded:
NUMERO



Num√©risation et Restitution de la frise dionysiaque¬†du th√©√¢tre d'Orange

Le projet Num√©RO vise √† appliquer les techniques de mod√©lisation en 3 dimensions √† un objet arch√©ologique fragment√©, la frise dionysiaque marmor√©enne provenant du d√©cor de la¬†frons scaenae¬†du th√©√¢tre d‚ÄôOrange, en vue de sa restitution virtuelle. Il a b√©n√©fici√© du soutien du programme Convergence ¬´¬†Science et Patrimoine culturel¬†¬ª de Sorbonne Universit√©s et s‚Äôest fond√© sur la collaboration de l‚ÄôInstitut scientifique du Calcul et des donn√©es (UPMC ‚Äì Sorbonne Universit√©s), de l‚ÄôEA 4081 ‚Äì Rome et ses renaissances (Universit√© Paris IV ‚Äì Paris-Sorbonne) et de l‚ÄôInstitut de Recherche sur Architecture Antique (USR 3155 du CNRS). Ce projet interdisciplinaire pr√©voit √©galement la conception d‚Äôoutils num√©rique sp√©cifiques d‚Äôanalyse, de mesure et d‚Äôimagerie 3D qui pourront √™tre d√©ploy√©s sur le mur de visualisation immersive et interactive 3D de l‚ÄôISCD.
Men√© sous la direction d‚ÄôEmmanuelle Rosso (EA 4081 ‚Äì Rome et ses renaissances ‚Äì Universit√© Paris IV ‚Äì Paris-Sorbonne) et au c≈ìur de l‚Äôinterdisciplinarit√©, le projet Num√©RO mobilise des comp√©tences en arch√©ologie, en architecture, en histoire de l‚Äôart, en math√©matiques et en informatique pour la num√©risation de fragments de la frise conserv√©s, le d√©veloppement des solutions logicielles personnalis√©es et le processus de restitution iconographique et de restauration num√©rique de la frise. A terme, le d√©cor ainsi restitu√© et mod√©lis√© de la frise viendra enrichir la maquette tridimensionnelle interactive et immersive du monument.

The Roman Theatre of Orange

The better-preserved roman theatre in Europe

The Dionysiac frieze

Life of Dionysus decorating the better-preserved roman theatre in Europe

Photogrammetry

3D data acquisition methods serving archaeologists

La photogramm√©trie est une technique de relev√© num√©rique tridimensionnel. Invent√©e d√®s 1849 par Aim√© de Laussadet, cette technique conna√Æt une nouvelle impulsion ces derni√®res ann√©es par l‚Äôav√®nement de la photographie num√©rique et est d√©sormais employ√©e dans les domaines des sciences humaines, notamment en arch√©ologie pour la num√©risation d‚Äôobjets ou de sites en 3D. Compl√©mentaire ou concurrente de la lasergramm√©trie, la photogramm√©trie est pr√©f√©r√©e pour son adaptabilit√©, sa relative facilit√©e de mise en ≈ìuvre et sa capacit√© √† r√©pondre √† des besoins en terme de r√©sultats. La photogramm√©trie consiste √† effectuer des mesures dans une sc√®ne, en utilisant la parallaxe obtenue entre des images acquises selon des points de vue diff√©rents. Fond√© sur le principe de la st√©r√©oscopie, elle a longtemps exploit√© la vision st√©r√©oscopique humaine pour reconstituer le relief de la sc√®ne √† partir de cette diff√©rence de points de vue. Actuellement, elle exploite de plus en plus les calculs de corr√©lation entre des images d√©sormais num√©riques. Cette technique repose enti√®rement sur une mod√©lisation rigoureuse de la g√©om√©trie des images et de leur acquisition afin de reconstituer une copie 3D exacte de la r√©alit√©, √† l‚Äô√©chelle et texturis√©e. Dans le cadre du projet interdisciplinaire Num√©RO, les 74 fragments en marbre de Carrare provenant de la frise ont fait l‚Äôobjet d‚Äôune num√©risation compl√®te par photogramm√©trie lors des quatre campagnes d‚Äôacquisition programm√©es en janvier, en avril, en octobre et en d√©cembre 2015 dans le respect du protocole d‚Äôacquisition d√©velopp√© et mis en place par notre √©quipe.

item.title: Molecular dynamics
item.dc:creator: loicNorgeot
item.content:encoded:
Molecular dynamics

Roadmap to exascale algorithms in chemistry

Molecular modelling encompasses all theoretical methods and computational techniques used to model the behaviour of molecules. The techniques are used in the fields of computational chemistry, drug design, computational biology and materials science for studying molecular systems ranging from small chemical systems to large biological molecules and material assemblies, to cite a few. Applications can be found in research (theoretical chemistry and physics) as well as in industry (materials sciences, biochemistry, biophysics). Nowadays, colossal computers resources are required to perform molecular modelling of any reasonably sized system. The common feature of molecular modelling techniques is the atomistic level description of the molecular systems and this includes treating atoms as the smallest individual unit (as in Molecular Dynamics) or explicitly modelling electrons and nuclei of each atom (as in Quantum Chemistry).

Simulating for understanding

A molecule can be seen as a collection of N moving particles of different masses and charges bound by electrostatic forces. Their behaviour is described by a wave function, which is solution to the quantum differential equation introduced by E. Schr√∂dinger and extended to the relativistic case by P. Dirac almost a century ago. At this time, the mathematical foundation of chemistry was understood. The complications arise with systems containing a large number of particles: it appeared impossible to find an expression of the exact solution for a system of arbitrary complexity. Following Dirac‚Äôs intuition, ‚Äúit therefore becomes desirable that approximate practical methods of applying quantum mechanics should be developed, which can lead to an explanation of the main features of complex atomic systems without too much computation‚Äù. Fortunately, this statement impacted strongly the chemistry community and marked the advent of an era of intense mathematical investigation. The expectation shifted from the dream of finding exact solutions to the pragmatic approach of introducing and analysing ‚Äútheoretical models that are approximate but well-defined mathematical procedures of simulation.

A strategy to tackle complexity

The purpose of any mathematical model in chemistry is to use a priori knowledge of the particle system to understand and predict the behaviour of any molecule. This proceeds in five stages: i) selecting a targeted accuracy: data must be predicted within a chosen accuracy like in experimental measurements, ii) introducing a mathematical formulation, general and continuous, as much as possible, iii) implementing the method: this involves appropriate discretisation methods and solution algorithms developed in efficient computer programs, iv) assessing the model: check it against databases to determine whether the target has been attained, and v) applying the model to problems for which the solution is unknown. The objective is not only to get quantitatively (more) accurate results but also to contribute to a better understanding of the molecular structures and processes. Researchers at ISCD focus on two complementary yet inextricably intertwined issues: i) how to introduce certification and validation in models and ii) how to develop dedicated algorithms that allow performances to increase linearly with computer power. To achieve this, classical chemistry models have to be coupled with quantum chemistry models. This requires implementing multi-scale methods and algorithms.

Molecular interactions

Numerical methods

Applications

item.title: Shape optimization
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
Shape optimization

the quest for the optimal shape

Shape optimization, loosely speaking, consists in finding an optimal design for a domain, a piece or a device, which minimizes a certain cost functional and satisfies some given constraints. Indeed, the optimization of the topology and the geometry of domains or structures has a great impact on its performance. In a classical optimization problem, the variables to optimize are functions or parameters. For instance, in automotive or aerospace industry the design variables are commonly geometrical parameters such as length, width or thickness of the part being optimized. On the other hand, the objective of shape optimization is to optimize the topological and geometrical structure of the domain itself. In most cases, the functional to be optimized depends on the solution of a partial differential equation defined on the domain. Due to their complex nature, such shape optimization problems are usually solved numerically by using iterative methods. Researchers at ISCD are developing new approaches to shape optimization that combines and retains the advantages of former optimization techniques, in which the shapes in the design space are represented implicitly as level sets of a higher-dimensional function. When coupled with the underlying equations of structural or fluid dynamics, it has a broad range of applications (automotive and aerospace engineering, pharmaceutical engineering, biomedical engineering, medicine, etc.

Optimizing shape

An old concern albeit a current active field of research

The first examples of shape optimization date back a long time ago. Let us recall the famous isoperimetric problem of the Queen Dido of Carthage, around 814 BC. Dido landed on the shores of north Africa, and asked a local Berber king, Larbas, a small portion of land to erect a city. King Larbas replied that he would grant her as much land as she could encompass with an ox-hide. Dido then slit the ox-hide into very thin strips, which she glued together, then used to delimit a region of maximum area, comprising a portion of the seashore, the length of the strip being fixed. Her strip of oxhide reached the shape of an arc of circle meeting the sea, which was to become the boundary of the territory of Byrsa (Fig. Dido building Carthage, W. Turner, 1815). Several centuries later, ca. 1685, Isaac Newton attempted to find the shape of a body opposing the slightest possible resistance to the motion when immersed in a fluid, while making some rather drastic assumptions. In the same period, the problem of the shape of a hanging chain (the catenary) was posed and solved. A century later, in 1773, Lagrange formulated the problem of finding the shape of an axisymmetric column of prescribed volume, which guarantees maximal resistance against buckling when submitted to axial compression efforts. Using the calculus of variations, he concluded that the cylinder was the optimal shape he was searching for. Unfortunately, his findings were flawed and further developments evidenced that better shapes can be achieved. Others, including Thomas Jefferson, considered questions such as the optimal shape for ploughshares. Since then, shape optimization has been enjoying numerous developments, both in terms of theoretical and numerical techniques.

Dido's problem revisited

What is the closed curve which has the maximum area for a given perimeter ? The solution of this problem by means of the calculus of variations was completed by Weierstrass in 1879, but not published at that time. Dido‚Äôs problem is about maximizing the area bounded by a closed parametrized curve described by its position $\gamma(t)=(x(t), y(t))$ and velocity $(\dot x(t),\dot y(t))$, subject to the constraint of having a fixed length. The area is defined as: $$\frac{1}{2}\int (x \dot y - y\dot x) \, dt,$$ while the perimeter is: $$\int \sqrt{\dot x^2 + \dot y^2}\, dt$$ Let us consider the function $$F = \frac{1}{2} (x \dot y - y\dot x) - \lambda \sqrt{\dot x^2 + \dot y^2}$$ and look for a maximum of $\int F(t)\, dt$. The latter if found by solving the Euler-Lagrange equations $$\frac{\partial F}{\partial x}- \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial \dot x}\right) = 0\,, \quad \frac{\partial F}{\partial y}- \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{\partial F}{\partial \dot y}\right) = 0$$ Differentiating these equations gives: $$\frac{1}{2}\dot y - \frac{d}{dt}\left(-\frac{1}{2}y - \lambda \frac{\dot x}{\sqrt{\dot x^2 + \dot y^2}}\right) = 0\,, \quad -\frac{1}{2}\dot x - \frac{d}{dt}\left(\frac{1}{2}x - \lambda \frac{\dot y}{\sqrt{\dot x^2 + \dot y^2}}\right) = 0\,.$$ Given the arclength parameter $t$, integrating both sides these simplify to $$\dot y +\lambda \ddot x = 0 \,,\quad -\dot x +\lambda \ddot y = 0$$ which yields the solution: $$x=x_0 + \lambda \cos\frac{t-t_0}{\lambda}\,, \quad y=y_0 + \lambda\sin\frac{t-t_0}{\lambda}$$ squaring and summing gives: $$(x-x_0)^2 + (y-y_0)^2 = \lambda^2$$ which is the equation of a circle of center $(x_0,y_0)$ and of radius $\lambda$. Knowing the perimeter $p$, it is easy to deduce the value of $\lambda$.

Computational methods

A quick overview

Various shape optimization techniques were introduced in computational mechanics in the early 60‚Äôs. Their main differences are related to the representation of shapes, and to the computation of the sensitivity of the objective criterion with respect to the design. Describing and deforming shapes is not a trivial problem as shape optimization techniques require to be able to perform mechanical computations, and the representation must allow for a robust account of shapes‚Äô deformations.

Shape representation

Multiple descriptions of shapes have been proposed, for instance: - shapes can be described explicitly: a surface ${\cal S} \subset \mathbb{R}^3$ is a covering set of local patches $\{(\sigma_i,U_i)\}_{i\in I}$ such that ${\cal S} =\bigcup\limits_{i\in I} U_i$, each (polynomial or rational) application $\sigma_i$ maps a portion of $\mathbb{R}^2$ to a portion of $\cal S$. - shape can also be described implicitly: the boundary is described using an auxiliary function defined on a large computational domain, but the shape itself is not explicitly represented. Level Set or Phase Field are examples of such methods.
item.excerpt:encoded: Shape optimization: how to find the shape which is optimal, i.e., minimizing a given cost functional under specific constraints.

item.title: Groupe de travail visualisation
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
Le but de ces rencontres informelles est de r√©unir des gens d'horizons diff√©rents, int√©ress√©s par les aspects math√©matiques de la visualisation.
Pour toute question ou suggestion, contactez l'organisateur Pierre-Antoine Guih√©neuf.


prochaines s√©ances


Vendredi 10 novembre 2017

√Ä 14h en salle 33-34-201

Mathieu Carri√®re

Sliced Wasserstein Kernel for Persistence Diagrams
Persistence diagrams (PDs) play a key role in topological data analysis (TDA), in which they are routinely used to describe topological properties of complicated shapes. PDs enjoy strong stability properties and have proven their utility in various learning contexts. They do not, however, live in a space naturally endowed with a Hilbert structure and are usually compared with non-Hilbertian distances, such as the bottleneck distance. To incorporate PDs in a convex learning pipeline, several kernels have been proposed with a strong emphasis on the stability of the resulting RKHS distance w.r.t. perturbations of the PDs. In this article, we use the Sliced Wasserstein approximation of the Wasserstein distance to define a new kernel for PDs, which is not only provably stable but also discriminative (with a bound depending on the number of points in the PDs) w.r.t. the first diagram distance between PDs. We also demonstrate its practicality, by developing an approximation technique to reduce kernel computation time, and show that our proposal compares favorably to existing kernels for PDs on several benchmarks.



S√©ances pass√©es


Vendredi 20 octobre 2017

Pierre-Vincent Koseleff

Diagrammes de Chebyshev et n≈ìuds √† 2 ponts
Avec D. Pecker, nous avons montr√© que tout n≈ìud de ${\mathbf R}^3 \subset {\mathbf S}^3$ est un n≈ìud de Chebyshev, ie admet une repr√©sentation polynomiale de la forme $(T_a(t),T_b(t), T_c(t+\phi))$ o√π $a,b,c$ sont des entiers, $\phi \in \mathbf Q$ et $T_n$ est le polyn√¥me de Chebyshev $x \mapsto \cos( n \arccos x)$. Avec F. Rouillier et C. Tran, nous avons propos√© un algorithme pour identifier les n≈ìuds de Chebyshev √† 2 ponts (cas $a=3$, $(a,b)=1$, $c$ fix√© et $\phi$ variant). L'expos√© abordera les diff√©rents aspects de ce probl√®me et sa g√©n√©ralisation.

Vendredi 21 avril 2017

Antonin Guilloux

Approche exp√©rimentale des vari√©t√©s de dimension 3
Un cocktail d'arguments th√©oriques, de consid√©rations combinatoires et de calculs effectifs permet de faire des exp√©riences sur des milliers de vari√©t√©s de dimension 3, notamment avec le logiciel SnapPy et ses extensions. Je pr√©senterai cette approche exp√©rimentale, en essayant d'en montrer les int√©r√™ts, limites et difficult√©s.

Vendredi 3 mars 2017

Julien Tierny et Gregory Ginot

Homologie persistente

Vendredi 10 f√©vrier 2017

S√©ance de pr√©sentation

item.title: Research Teams
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
Multidisciplinary Research

Since 2010, the ISCD holds a central place for interdisciplinary research in scientific computing, data analysis and scientific visualisation at Sorbonne Universit√©. Today, it integrates a few main and junior research projects from the three faculties: sciences, medicine and humanities, that share office space, administrative staff and computer resources.

Main Team-Projects

  • Computational Methods for Biology
    Prof. A. Carbone (LQCB)

    In genomics and bioinformatics, algorithms are used to explore data and discover laws of evolution that affect genomes and molecules and that requires validation against experimental data. Bayesian analysis of many statistical models leads to massively parallel computation for which the next generation of computers is well suited. In integrative genomics analysis, multivariate models have to be implemented in ultra-high dimensional data and coupled with inferential algorithms that search over vast model spaces. As the size of the genomics data sets and the number of samples are constantly increasing, the mathematical computations as well as the computational complexity become exponentially more expensive.
    [Read more...]

  • Mathematics for Computational Chemistry
    Prof. J.P. Piquemal (LCT), Prof. E. Canc√®s (Ecole des Ponts)

    The molecular Schr√∂dinger equation which is associated with the molecular Hamiltonian involved in the computational chemistry programmes, has been scrutinised with the help of mathematicians and computer scientists and major breakthroughs have been achieved regarding theoretical as well as computational issues. Two Grand Challenges, i) Linear Scaling in Computational Chemistry and ii) Molecule Energy Approximation in Computational Chemistry, relate to computing at extreme scales and require multidisciplinary teams to develop the necessary models and programs for the next generation of supercomputers.
    [Read more...]

Junior Teams

  • Digital Archaeology
    Dr. E. Rosso (Rome et ses renaissances)

    This project is concerned by the use of data and computational methods for archaeological studies. Emerging technologies allow researchers to look at ancient objects in entirely new ways, to reveal hidden features or build and explore virtual models of heritage materials.
    [Read more...]

  • Mathematical Models for Forensic Sciences
    Prof. Y. Maday (LJLL), Prof. P. Goudot (SCMF, AP-HP)

    Research conducted in this group relates to the use of mathematical models for facial reconstruction for enhancing the identification of deceased people when the skeletal remains is the sole information available. Digital methods allow to eliminate the subjectivity of reconstruction processes and to test different hypothesis and propose multiple instances of reconstruction.
    [Read more...]

  • Scientific Visualisation
    Dr. J. Tierny (LiP6), Dr. P.A. Guih√©neuf (IMJ)

    Computational disciplines, like bioinformatics, chemistry, scientific computing, data analysis, use extensively the visualisation engines (algorithms) for interpreting lab data and for training purposes. This group is concerned by the design of new theoretical concepts and computational methods for improving the understanding of the data being explored.
    [Read more...]

  • Health Care, Personalized Medicine
    Prof. L. Mesnard (H. Tenon), Prof. F. Corn√©lis (H. Tenon)

    The future of health care is a system in which patient care is improved through the use of information on the patient's data (genomes, images, signals, etc.). The group uses predictive tools to evaluate health risks, and to design personalized health plans to help patients mitigate risks, revent disease, and to treat it more accuratel when it occurs.
    [Read more...]

  • Digital Humanities
    Prof. D. Alexandre (UFR de litt√©rature fran√ßaise et de litt√©rature compar√©e)

    When computing technologies cross the disciplines of the humanities, new ways of investigating words and texts, new kinds of teaching and research happen, in a dual relationship between the humanities and the digital. This group is interested in the study of translations, transpositions, adaptations to understand how the canons are formed.
    [Read more...]

International Relations

Scientists associated with the ISCD have established numerous international collaborations worldwide. Moreover, institutional agreements have been set up between UPMC-Sorbonne Universit√© and other universities, both in Europe and abroad; and, in most cases, Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) have been signed.

Transfer with Industry

Since its creation, the ISCD has set up collaborative projects with the industry, especially with small or medium-size enterprises. Our research groups have produced relevant computational results and efficient software that are now transferred to industry through collaborations, joint projects and partnerships. In addition, the ISCD is actively participating in the Institut Carnot Smiles, which aims at developing new forms of collaborations between industry and academia.

item.title: EmC2: Maximum Probability Domains
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
Dr. Guillaume Acke (U. Ghent, Belgium),
Summary: The Lewis model of the chemical bond treats electrons as discrete pairs, localized in a certain region of space. On the other hand, the molecular orbital approach to quantum chemistry considers electrons as delocalized over the entire space. Many new ways to extract Lewis-structural information from the wave function have been suggested, providing links between quantum and traditional chemistry.
One of these novel approaches is the use of maximum probability domains (MPDs) [1][2]. This method statistically localizes electrons in domains, by determining those regions of 3D space for which the probability of finding a given number of electrons is maximal. This method has successfully been applied to interpret covalent and ionic bonding [3][4]. However, MPDs have not yet been characterized by other chemical descriptors, which leaves their links with other conceptual quantities ill described. Furthermore, MPDs obtained from current implementations suffer from numerical inaccuracy, which clouds their properties [5].
In this presentation, I will introduce the theory of MPDs, extend it with novel concepts and novel algorithms. I will show how this theory can be applied to a range of chemical phenomena, and how this interpretation can lead to increased chemical understanding.
[1] Savin A; Sen KD (ed) In: Reviews of modern quantum chemistry. A celebration of the contributions of Robert G Parr. World Scientific, Singapore, p 43 (2002)
[2] Canc√®s, E.; Keriven, R.; Lodier, F.; Savin, A. How electrons guard the space: shape optimization with probability distribution criteria, Theor. Chem. Acc. 111, 373-380 (2004)
[3] Caus√†, M.; D‚ÄôAmore, M; Garzillo, C.; Gentile, F.; Savin, A. The Bond Analysis Techniques (ELF and Maximum Probability Domains) Application‚Ä®to a Family of Models Relevant to Bio-Inorganic Chemistry, Struct. Bond, 150, 119-142 (2013)

item.title: 39th ORAP Forum: Emerging and future HPC architectures around the world
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
This ORAP Forum will explore two topics. International (China, Japan) and European projects presentations will be an opportunity to emphasize the rising interest for ARM-based HPC architectures, among other considerations and visions delivered by large players. Trends in I/O and storage for HPC will then be highlighted by academic or industrial experts, from technology to applications, emphasizing also new concepts and software organization aspects.

These two topics are not disconnected: usage evolution in all domains is questioning an increasingly intertwined vision of computing and data processing. This will be illustrated by the different technical, scientific or strategic presentations, and we will be able to discuss how more and more crucial data movement and storage features and capabilities must be globally envisioned.

More information.

item.title: 6th ISCD summer school: bioinformatics and visual data analysis
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
Scientific trends at the interfaces:
bioinformatics and visual data analysis

This summer school program is perfect for undergraduate students (L3-M2) considering studying theoretical or computational sciences at university level. It comprises intensive courses which aim to provide attendees with an introduction to both the theoretical foundations and the practical applications of some of the modern mathematical and computational techniques currently in use. Each course has theoretical and practical classes, in which students can experiment each technique with computers.

The summer school will take place a the Marine Station in Roscoff.

Registrations are now open, until May 15, 2017. Follow this link

item.title: SMF summer school: Structured Regularization for High-Dimensional Data Analysis
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
The SMF (French Mathematical Society) and the Institut Henri Poincar√© organize a mathematical summer school on "Structured Regularization for High-Dimensional Data Analysis". This summer school will be the opportunity to bring together students, researchers and people working on High-Dimensional Data Analysis around three courses and four talks on new methods in structured regularization. The mathematical foundations of this event will lie between probability, statistics, optimization, image and signal processing.

Courses: * Anders Hansen (Cambridge) * Andrea Montanari (Stanford) * Lorenzo Rosasco (Genova and MIT)

Talks: * Francis Bach (INRIA and ENS) * Claire Boyer (UPMC) * Emilie Chouzenoux (Paris Est) * Carlos Fernandez-Granda (NYU)

Organizers: * Yohann De Castro (Paris-Sud) * Guillaume Lecu√© (CNRS and ENSAE) * Gabriel Peyr√© (CNRS and ENS)

More information (including registration, free but mandatory) is available on the webpage.

item.title: Open positions: research engineers
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
Two research engineer positions (fixed term) are currently available at ISCD.

Applications are welcomed for the research engineer positions, working with the project-teams on several collaborative research projects (healthcare analytics, scientific computing, HPC).

The positions are funded by the institute for computing and data science and aims to develop next-generation technology for data intensive research. You will have demonstrated experience in high performance computing (HPC) and expertise in a subset of the skills outlined hereafter.

Required skills and knowledge:

  • Master degree or PhD (preferred) in Applied Mathematics, Informatics, Computational or Physical Science, Engineering or equivalent area;
  • Extensive knowledge of High Performance Computing
  • Experience within a research-based scientific computing environment;
  • Demonstrated development experience with a variety of programming languages, tools and technologies (Java/C++, Python/Perl).

To apply for these vacancies, follow this link.

item.title: Conference in honor of Yvon Maday (60th birthday)
item.dc:creator: frey
item.content:encoded:
This conference is organized for the 60th birthday of Yvon Maday in honor of his many major contributions in applied mathematics, numerical analysis and scientific computing.

Location: Conference Center of the Roscoff Marine Station, Roscoff, France 02-05 May 2017

In the context of these achievements, the conference will focus on domain decomposition methods, reduced basis methods and related algorithms, modeling and analysis for coupled problems, and a priori and a posteriori analysis for discretisation schemes.

More information at the website.

item.title: Release of the Topology Toolkit
item.dc:creator: icsadm
item.content:encoded:
Released by researchers and engineers from the LIP6 lab , the Topology ToolKit (TTK) is an open-source library and software collection which provides a substantial collection of generic, efficient and robust implementations of key algorithms in topological data analysis.

More information is available on the project website.
item.excerpt:encoded: The Topology ToolKit (TTK) is an open-source library and software collection for topological data analysis in scientific visualization.
